While you have the dying condition, you’re bleeding out or otherwise at death’s door. You’re unconscious while you have the dying condition. Dying always includes a value. If this value ever reaches dying 4, you die. While you're dying, attempt a recovery check at the start of each of your turns. This is a flat check with a DC equal to 10 + your current dying value to see if you get better or worse.

Critical Success Your dying value is reduced by 2.
Success Your dying value is reduced by 1.
Failure Your dying value increases by 1.
Critical Failure Your dying value increases by 2.
If you take damage while you already have the dying condition, increase your dying condition value by 1, or by 2 if the damage came from an attacker’s critical hit or your own critical failure.

You lose the dying condition if it ever reaches dying 0. If you're still at 0 Hit Points, you remain unconscious, but you can wake up as described in that condition. You lose the dying condition automatically and wake up if you ever have 1 Hit Point or more.

Anytime you lose the dying condition, you gain the wounded 1 condition, or increase your wounded value by 1 if you already have that condition.

You have a Dexterity modifier cap to your AC of +0, meaning you don’t add your Dexterity to your AC, and your Speeds are all reduced by 5 feet. The item bonus to AC from Mountain Stance is cumulative with armor potency runes on your explorer’s clothing, mystic armor, and bands of force.

A pair of pixie wings were used to create this pretty blade - their delicate tracings can be seen all day and night, though they shine brightest by the light of a gibbous moon.
Smoke-like whorls of sussur sap darken the metal of this dagger's blade and silence its victims.

Cazador's love of poetry arose after he read one on the naked stomach of a dead child in his homeland. The child was hung from the lowest branch of a tree. Cazador read the poem, and looked at the child, and he knew that here was the artform for him.
The dagger's twisting blade is designed to nick the flesh as many times as possible, allowing its paralytic poison to flow effortlessly into any unfortunate target.

The Lord of Murder wasn't always a lord. He was once just a petty killer. When Bhaal first drew blood in a Baldurian back-alley, it dropped to the ground and lingered. When he ascended, this dried blood-drop grew, warped - and became sharp.
Acid was long ago abandoned by assassins, who found poison much more reliable in spiking their targets' drinks. The acid kept melting the chalices.
This flail was created to commemorate victory over the devil Belhifet. It has since made its way so far from Easthaven that the locals have long forgotten that chapter of their town's past.
Created by a warmongering rakshasa and kept for a time under the careful watch of an astute noble named Lord de'Arnise, this flail is a tool of absolute destruction, and a versatile one at that.

Kereska, the draconic goddess of arcane knowledge, gifted this glaive to a dragonborn when facing off against a group of carbuncular spiders. How their arachnid legs curled and blackened before that night's dark business was done!

Monster-slaying is a rare calling, not for the faint of heart. It requires temperance, discipline, and usually a very big stick with something pointy at the end.
The best thing about spears is that the ugly parts of combat are happening at the other end.
A gift from Dame Aylin and her radiant goddess, this weapon's contours hold a silver-white beauty akin to the nightly lantern that climbs the firmament each evening.
For every drop of blood spilled, a piece of the soul perishes - until nothing remains but regret.
Wielded by the indomitable Ser Lexia. Although her eagerness to destroy evil in all its forms was constant, she often took time to make little gifts for her friends.
Stained brown and reeking of iron, this greataxe once belonged to a killer so deranged, his name was magically scrubbed from all histories.
The power of this axe lies in a fluctuating arcane enchantment that flows between the beard and the edge of the axe, and the wielder themselves.
Anything hit by this has the life expectancy of a glass hammer.
When this axe careens through the air toward an unfortunate head - the whistle of its spiritual counterpart is never far behind.
You see... *hic* the thing... the really, really important thing *hic*... about this item is *belches copiously*... oh sod it, it's a club. Enjoy.
Few things solve a disagreement faster than displaying a greatclub. And this one reeks, too.
A club with nails hammered through it. Classic.
Though heavily decorated and inlaid with rubies, the blade's sharp edge suggests its use isn't merely ornamental.

Wielded by Svartlebee The Custodian, so named because he had the following reputation: Have you got someone in your life causing a mess? Send Svartlebee a missive. He shall clean them up, and then clean up the crime scene.
The words 'Deliverance. Justice. Vengeance.' are engraved on the base of this sword. They echo in your mind.
Strong castle-forged steel surmounts a grip of sturdy leather - this immense sword is capable of disembowelling giants in a single swipe.
The sharp metal whispers to you. Pleading. Cursing... Echoes of slain foes.
Sussur roots extend from this sword's hilt into the blade itself. It yearns to drink magic, silencing every creature it strikes.
The sword of Sarevok, brother of Gorion's Ward and child of the evil god Bhaal. Though much of its power died with him, the sword is still formidable, and glows with a malevolent light.

Wielded by Balduran, the founder of Baldur's Gate and friend to his guardian dragon, a great glittering wyrm called Ansur. Fellowship can be undone, though, as easily as you or I might unlace the strings of our shoes, and it was in a time of skullduggery and hardship that Balduran killed Ansur, carrying out the deed with this sword.
Silver Sword of the Astral Plane

The fervour with which the githyanki express devotion to their queen is admirable to some, disquieting to others. When confronted with the fallibility of the divine (since no one is wholly perfect), who knows what reaction such folk might evince.
Small lodestones have been inserted along the halberd's shaft, a strange blue current running through them.
Sharp teeth grow out of the halberd's dark metal - if it is indeed metal at all.
In mellow light, the halberd's curved steel head eerily resembles a grin.

The platinum inlays of this halberd hum an otherworldly harmony in the key of C, heightening the wielder's vigour but diminishing their mental faculties. The sound it makes is pining, as if far from its rightful home.
Salvaged from the beard of a dead infernal leviathan, whose facial hair was formed from the weapons of an army it had once vanquished.

A variant of this halberd's design was thrown out in the early stages of development by its forgemaster. This was because the halberd kept expressing itself. 'ALARM!' it would shriek in peril. 'POTENCY FILLS ME LIKE A SONG OF HOPE!' it roared in triumph.
On the stock, the crafter of this crossbow etched in tiny print: 'Ifn yer gonna miss, why dontchyae stop being a wally, and hit instead!'
Rigged to draw on the skin-peeling hellfire of Avernus by a resourceful devil, this crossbow's size is no indication of its deadly potential.
This loyal axe always returns to its owner after being thrown. However, it has no eyes and therefore dreadful aim, inevitably returning to its thrower blade-end-first.
The soft hum of power emanates from the alien metal.

When Gandrel was seven, he was frightened badly by a vampire spawn during a public burning. Seized by the flames, the creature didn't shrivel up. It swelled and burst like a squeezed leech. Brains splattered the boy's shoes, grey-pink and pulpy. He would never forget it.
Legends say the Giantbreaker earned its name when an elven ranger singlehandedly defeated a score of hill giants. While the ranger's name is long forgotten, Giantbreaker's lives on.
This heavy crossbow is fashioned from a curious, tensile metal that doesn't seem to be native to Faerûn.
Named after Harold Butterbisk, who owned the Butterbisk Inn in Waterdeep before it was renamed by new owners. The stock of the crossbow reads: Quaffing is a shootable offence.
A perfect system must be ruled by a keen eye - and any error foolish enough to rear its head afore the eye must be quickly, precisely, and totally eliminated. This crossbow can help with that.

'Trundling, mashing, mincing, crushing, grinding, blasting, biting! Hear their peeling thunder, their roaring flames, their clicking, whirring, metallic melody, and know that the hellfire engines of Avernus are on the move!' - Edict in Elturel
The Long Arm of the Gur
A sleek, well-made crossbow that is plain but for the symbol of Shar on the handle.
Look no further than Scyllua Darkhope - fallen paladin and champion of Bane - to see how the tools of good can be turned to evil purpose.
And they shall have Celestia's light, even if we must crack wide the heavens to bring it."
Constructs and objects melt beneath this hefty blunt tool when wielded by a sharp mind.
This longbow was forged from the remnants of Stanislav the Silver's shield, found near the wreckage of Castle Ravenloft some years ago.
The commonly held belief that archers are rangey, thin-wristed people is completely false. It takes years of training to pull a bowstring all the way back to your cheekbone, and wrists like iron.
When the archer Frederik Durlusk died, his only request was to be buried with his favourite bow. This is that bow.

Gontr Mael blasted from the corpse of the Steel Watcher Titan: a bow formed from the boiling slag and weird whispering gyros inherent to the mechanical giant. It must have acted as the Titan's abdomen, exchanging muscle for immaculate steel.
Every tip and edge on this elaborate sword is sharpened to a deadly perfection.
The hilt of this slender sword is wrapped with soft, black silk - the dark colour hiding any possible stains.
Though heavy, this longsword swings effortlessly in your hand - ready to take down a hundred enemies.
Formerly wielded by one who forsook all ties of friendship and kindness, this sword is rife with deranged energies. It seems to transmit feelings of contentment when carving through bones.

Fragments of dead souls are imprisoned in the steel. Angry, powerful, hopeful, or scared - all of them rose up against their illithid masters, and all of them fell to this blade. Now, they are trapped forever, forced to aid their oppressors.

The trauma of becoming a drider is quickly set aside with a cold arachnid dispassion. This sword follows that disturbing trend - a replenishing poison gland is built within, deployed only against trapped opponents.

Cradling his newborn son awkwardly, the Duke's face pulled into a rictus of misery. His love Francesca smiled at him, briefly, and died. He stared at her until the boy cried, and he told the boy it would be all right, though he himself did not believe it.
Deceptively light, the blade rasps through castle-forged plate as easily as Corellon Larethian's own anarchic holy sword through the hearts of evil orcs.
The drow inscription on this blade appears to have been recently carved. It translates to: 'Though I have to leave you, I will dance forever in Eilistraee's light.'
There's a graceful swarthiness to this sword. The inscription in the steel reads - 'My eye wanders far from home / To shores of distant Anchorome.'
Heavy and grouted in the gore of countless centuries, this prototype for the contemporary githyanki silver sword was wielded during their rebellion against the mind flayers who enslaved them.
Precise infernal runes are woven into this weapon's filigree, implying a creator well-versed in hellish arcana.
Cast deep in the Underdark by duergar slaves, the head of this mace is engraved with spiderwebs. It is ice-cold to the touch.
A nimble mace, heavy with the promise of broken bones.
A bundle of bones and blood - and a soul-piercing demonic presence - is all that remains of the Flind's flail. It would make a decent mace with a particularly nasty bite.

This mace was designed by Lolth's assassins to fell heretics who dared turn their back on the Spider Queen. However, even the best-laid designs fall to nothingness when brought to bear against Shar's faithful.
This weapon is favoured by celestial devas, the vanguards of the divine ranks of paradise.

The large chunk of amber set into the handle of this luminous mace supposedly holds four drops of godly blood, fallen to the earth in a battle between an avatar of Lathander and a maddened Chosen of Mystra.
Reliable and trustworthy, you could not hope for more respectable company than this maul whilst traversing the forlorn places of the world.

As heavy and opposed to nonsense as the kitchen cook in most stories about some young adventurous girl going to become a knight or a hedge witch or something. You've got to have a big no nonsense cook. It's like rules.
The power of this item lies in belief, though not in any god. This item believes that it's very good at hitting things, so it is. Belief is quite powerful when it comes to violence.
They say rich folk are never truly happy: especially true when they're targeted with this morningstar.
A 'Crazy Wilbur' is a technique invented by the dwarvish Ticklebeard Clan. It involves getting your larger enemies to swallow your weapon, then calling it back to you - as messily as possible.
Concussive energy thumps like a mighty heartbeat from this pike.
Yes, but what exactly is hitting you?

When the boy was seven, he was frightened badly by a vampire spawn during a public burning. Seized by the flames, the creature didn't shrivel up. It swelled and burst like a squeezed leech. Brains splattered the boy's shoes, grey-pink and pulpy.

He would never forget it.

In spite of (or perhaps because of) his suspiciously amusing name, the wizard Melf was actually quite a talented spellcaster and innovator in the field of the arcane. He even led an order called the Knights of Luna.
Often mistaken for a relic of the wizard Bigby's creation, this staff was, ironically, made as a bite stick for Bigby's dog, Bigboy.

Carved in circles across the knob of the staff are different words for thunder. Gnomish, Sylvan, Elvish, Celestial, even the Primordial tongue - all of these and more fuse together to form the thunderword.

The texture of magic granted by a warlock's patron is largely dependent upon the patron themselves - for example, your standard eldritch patron's probably going to work some eyeball-mottled tentacles in there somewhere.

Touching the adornments, it's clear that Lorroakan's short temper has flowed into his staff. It flows into your brain in shades of burgundy and carmine, bright as the storm-lanterns of Lorroakan's homeland.
The fire engulfing this staff seems to feed off thin air, never once burning the dark wood.
This quarterstaff is as solid as the bond between each member of the Harpers - even working in anonymity, they do so with a common and righteous cause.

This staff was wielded by Thibault Hollow, a supremely talented necromancer notable for his overwhelming fear of zombies. Many was the time when his dread lair would echo with a high-pitched shriek when one of them surprised him in a corridor, or when he was taking a bath.
This staff hums with a disruptive arcane energy that drives nearby spellcasters to distraction.

Ceremorphosis eradicates great swathes of the consciousness that came before... but not everything. Touching the staff, a fragment of the Emperor's memory slithers into your brain - you see sea waves foaming into spume, and feel the explorer's exultant joy.

Then the image is gone, like so much silken night under a cut-shade sun.
The air around this staff crackles with a cold, frosty wind - a power that has been divided for too long, and is waiting to be released.

Unlike their father, Thibault, Cherish Hollow was not afraid of zombies. Cherish was afraid of sharks, liquorice, wallpaper, Netherese artefacts, hats (large), the outdoors, the indoors, hats (small), and milk pails. Zombies were a bloody picnic.
A near-perfect relic that is only blemished by the collected palm-sweat of various archmagi from across the Realms.

Fashioned by some unknown archmage - no identifying insignia is forthcoming.

The staff thrums with a slow, ferocious pulse that draws its concussive power from the spiral-horned creatures that gave the weapon its name.

The gentle tap-tap-tap of a staff on stone sparked terror for all in Cazador's palace. It signalled an approaching storm, and all they could do was shrink into the background and pray its wrath would not fall on them.

Kereska, draconic goddess of arcane knowledge, imbues many chromatic dragons with their magic. This includes their exquisite and terrible breath, which has wrenched giants from their tall thrones, and destroyed civilisations of smallfolk.
This long, slender blade fits perfectly between the ribs of any unsuspecting victim.

Fashioned by some unknown archmage - no identifying insignia is forthcoming.

The staff thrums with a slow, ferocious pulse that draws its concussive power from the spiral-horned creatures that gave the weapon its name.
This dagger's handle is smooth and light, its jagged blade sharpened into a thin, cruel edge.
A light, slender blade, magically honed to stay razor-sharp.
Though the grip's leather is old and crusty, it shows no signs of wear, and not a single scratch mars the slender blade.
A standard, lightweight sword, suitable for both thrusting and slashing techniques.
The intricate engravings on this axe's blade and handle make plain the skill of its smith.
A long, deep crack runs through the side of the wood, filled with crusted blood.
A browning piece of brain sticks stubbornly to one of the spikes.
Fashioned by expert elven hands to be both deadly and beautiful.
A small prayer decorates the hilt of this axe. It resonates in your head when you touch it.
Without the wrapped leather grip, the weight of the slab of iron at the end of this greatclub would send it flying with a single swing.
The thick leather straps wrapped around the base of the blade creak under a solid grip.
This halberd's spike is black with ash that cannot be washed away.
This axe's hooked blade is crafted to cleave flesh and bone.
A subtle magic runs through both strings of this crossbow, keeping the bows even once the lock is released.
Despite the heaviness of this crossbow, the latch pulls back with an effortless ease.
The worn leather strap at the end of this javelin loops around the wrist to let it be thrown with devastating force.
Though this crossbow's stock is hollowed out, its heavy trigger mechanism keeps it well-balanced.
A skilful smith decorated the wooden handle with a fine golden filigree.
Carved enchantments span the length of this supple bow.
A complex filigree wraps around the base of this blade - the runes on the side suggesting it is not merely decorative.
The leather handle of this mace smells badly of rotting blood.
A weapon of dwarven make: elegant, but strong enough to last several human lifetimes.
It's said that one warrior with a morningstar is worth seventeen with a sword - one for each of the weapon's spikes.
The base of this polearm's shaft is splintered, likely having borne the weight of a rider plucked from their mount.
A polished wooden staff, embellished with knobs and steel for both function and design.
A lightweight sword that turns the slightest flick of a wrist into a deadly attack.
The phases of the moon are carved into the hilt of this scimitar, betraying a druid's careful hand.
Though dented in many places, this shield shines like new.
Despite numerous small scratches on the shield's surface, not a single blade has been able to make an actual dent in the heavy wood.
Small pockets of rust are starting to eat away at a few of the studs.
This thick oak shield is reinforced with a frame of rough-hammered iron.
This halfling bow requires a full draw for smaller folk, but serves as a quick off-hand for those of greater height.
Forged by dwarven hands, and prized by all warriors who wish to keep their foe at a distance.
The brutal design of this weapon's trio of prongs forces pierced flesh apart.
Following tradition, this hammer's faces were forged with grooves that sealed in the blood of its first kill.
When swung, the arc of this weapon perfectly matches the curve of its beak-like pick.
Though heavily decorated and inlaid with rubies, the blade's sharp edge suggests its use isn't merely ornamental.
This heavy crossbow is fashioned from a curious, tensile metal that doesn't seem to be native to Faerûn.
Every tip and edge on this elaborate sword is sharpened to a deadly perfection.
Despite its engravings, this lightweight sword is perfectly balanced - a flawless killing implement.
A pulse of magic shoots through your hands whenever you touch this axe.
The flail sits heavy in your hand - the weight of steel and magic.
Tiny specks of blood are fused into the blade, as if the glaive is feeding on them.
This heavy axe emits a barely audible hum when swung.
A blue glow radiates through the brass spirals at the end of this heavy club.
This greatsword's guard has been replaced with the spiked ball of a morningstar.
A deep scratch runs down one side of the axe blade. It thrums with magic.
Though the crossbow is small and light, a heavy power runs through its bowstring.
The crossbow feels weightless in your hands, as if held up by indiscernible currents of air.
The tell-tale glow of magical enchantment pulses along this javelin's hooked head.
Persistent rumours speak of magical crossbows that never miss their mark. While clearly exaggerated, every tale holds a kernel of truth.
Magic thrums through you with each blow of this hammer.
A soothing hum drifts through your head whenever you draw this bow.
This longsword never dulls, although an observer may notice it quietly drinks the blood of slain enemies.
The shallow etchings along this mace's head seem to change shape, depending on the light.
This massive hammer is inscribed with a battle chant in Giant, bidding the wielder to split the world in two.
The intense heat of dwarven forges has given the metal its shiny blue hue.
Tiny indentations in the groove along this pike's head emit a high-pitched whistle when thrust.
Steel bands wrap around a wooden core, giving this staff extra momentum.
The thin edge of this sword seems to blur and become nigh imperceptible with even the slightest movement.
An arched electric-blue afterimage follows this blade's every move.
This robust shield has been polished to a bright sheen.
Pliable yew and a hearty bowstring ensure this shortbow fires straight and true.
Even the ornamentation at the base of this spear's head is honed to a razor edge.
An elegant, vicious weapon designed to eviscerate flesh and organs.
The segmented design of this gnome-forged hammer borrows elements of dragonborn weaponry.
This weapon's slick steel point prevents it from catching in armour or bone.
Designed by gnomish innovation, this weapon has a dynamic core that swivels and tinkles into life whenever the axe is swung at a foe.
Fashioned from the hard, unforgiving trunk of an oak, this club still retains the perfume of the forest.
Odd to think that dark gods like Bhaal were once mortal. One wonders if they ever thumbed a wagon ride, thought about the weather, or ate flavoured yoghurt.
The leather handle is smooth with use, and slick with fresh blood.
The blade is sharp, and the handle firm. Yet death exudes from this dagger as it might from a fresh corpse.

Unlike their father, Thibault, Cherish Hollow was not afraid of zombies. Cherish was afraid of sharks, liquorice, wallpaper, Netherese artefacts, hats (large), the outdoors, the indoors, hats (small), and milk pails. Zombies were a bloody picnic.

The gentle tap-tap-tap of a staff on stone sparked terror for all in Cazador's palace. It signalled an approaching storm, and all they could do was shrink into the background and pray its wrath would not fall on them.

Kereska, draconic goddess of arcane knowledge, imbues many chromatic dragons with their magic. This includes their exquisite and terrible breath, which has wrenched giants from their tall thrones, and destroyed civilisations of smallfolk.
Imagine the soul as a blade. A good one, carefully looked after. A bad one suited for rusting in the rain. Flame-chewed and narrow, this blade is Wyll's soul summarised in steel.
After the blade had sliced Kas the Bloody-Handed's throat, it was chosen by Pelor, God of the sun, to do righteous work against the undead.

A blade gifted to Lora by her own mother, Lenore the Fleet. When challenged to duels, Lenore's opponents assumed she had received this nickname from some naval exploit. They found out how wrong they were when her blade blurred faster than the eye could follow.

Mortician Kurwin was known to use his trusty Cauteriser on all sorts of interesting subjects. At first these were cadavers, then people who wouldn't be missed, and it was only after he targeted a well-liked tavern owner that he was ratted out to the law.
Everything moves strangely in the Feywild, from rivers to behaviours. It's a mercurial place, where the magical and physical can pass permeably through one another.
Each cut of this blade shines with the wicked glint of adamantine - a promise for a devastating blow.
This blade is sharp and slender as a serpent's fang - and just as likely to inflict a hideous sting.

Faded but still legible, the mark of a Kara-Turan forgemaster adorns the pommel of this exquisite sword. Light as a robin's wing, quick as gnomish wit, this weapon has unseamed many foes - and will continue to, in the correct hands.
This light, curved blade is as unusual and unforgiving as the darkness it strikes from.

One of the relics of Deep Duerra's rebellious children. It was to the tremendous surprise of all that Ludmilla, the quiet, the weepy, the daughter most under her mother's thumb, took up this bow and fired.

The arrow flashed, and while Duerra and her blinded court wailed impotently, the children escaped into an uncertain, yet sweetly free, future.
Conducting a series of increasingly sick rituals - involving the ashes of a gnome and silkworms fed fat on the corpse of a dwarven cleric - the goblin shaman Kirruk Redrats created this deadly bow.
Quiet is the air around this sword, and quiet are the steps of the one who wields it.
A golden blade, exquisitely made and astonishingly sharp.
The previous owner was going to call this sword Barney, but he got such a bollocking from his friends that he named it Fleshrender instead, and sulked for a whole tenday afterward.

The wizard Otiluke wrote about bound weapons and their propensity to coalesce with their wielder as the pair come together. He also wrote about their dangers, which are manifold, and their benefits, which make the danger worth it.
Snatched from the realm of the mad wizard Halaster Blackcloak, this knife became a prized keepsake of a duergar king.

When she was a girl, she toyed with nastiness and sadism. Children often grow out of this; they get hobbies. For Orin, that taste for cruelty fermented, and in a way she did find hobbies. Ones that screamed.
The sheen of sussur sap forged into this sickle glows blue, silencing every creature it cuts.
The curve of this sickle evokes a pitiless crescent moon over turbulent seas.
A makeshift spear fashioned from a giant crab's claw and the charged imagination of kuo-toa fishfolk.
Precise infernal runes are woven into this weapon's filigree, implying a creator well-versed in hellish arcana.
There is an eager, annihilating darkness thrumming within this weapon - it begs to be used.

'One of the goddess Selûne's titles, Moonmaiden, has often been debated among the ecclesiastical. Common symbology certainly rejects the assumption of virginity. More to the point, 'maiden' itself carries some dusty connotations. How about Lunar Lady? Keeps the alliteration, too.' - Margaery Henderplum
When visiting mortals in dreams, Shar's hair would curl and twist about her head like strands of inky midnight. If it tickled her nose, the goddess was careful not to show it.

Time has dampened this spear's sheen, but the centre glows a faint blue. The magic it exudes feels old, terrible... and divine. The spear was given to its previous owner for his unerring loyalty - even after death.
When Yrre the Sparkstruck was asked why they'd created a trident twice their size, they simply replied, 'The question is why not?'

Umberlee, the goddess of the sea, is deeply capricious, intelligent, and not nearly as wet around the edges as her domain might suggest. She often demands sacrificial tribute from sailors, such as their ships, their cargo, and, while she's at it, them.

The forgemaster Lirrico designed this weapon for the champion of the wind goddess Akadi. A key component in the forging was his home city's wind, and for a year after the weapon was made, no wind blew there at all.
Countless hands have smoothened the haft and sharpened the blade. This is an ancestral weapon - perhaps dating back to the ancient digs that sundered the duergar from their dwarf-kin.
The elegant design of this hammer belies its brutal, crushing power. This weapon does not give ground.

Energy crackles in weird and wonderful patterns across your hand as you wield this bound weapon, as if your very veins were marbled like a cloud of blue-white lightning.
This hammer has a colourful history - it doesn't honk when you squeeze it, alas.
Tyr is often known as the Maimed God - a descriptor he shares with most victims of this heavy warhammer.

This hammer's weight is centred on enchanted obsidian at the base of the head. Some nights before bed, Ketheric would sneak a whey-faced glance at the hammer, and think about the stone, and wonder what unknown facet of his heart bore his weight.

The first Dwarven Thrower was created unintentionally. The moment was transcribed in the annals of dwarfdom thusly: 'Ach, it doesn't work. Another design down the bloody drain. Now to... Does er... Does anyone else hear a sort of humming whistle? Growing louder?'
Every contract a devil makes has some form of insurance - this one is cast in infernal iron and was forged in deep, ruinous hellfire.
Contrary to popular belief, your standard djinni doesn't grant wishes, unless that wish is to have your nose lopped off.
Toggle the Extending rune on/off, increasing the range of melee attacks to 60ft at a higher action cost.

A blade of flawless craft. As it parts the air, you fancy you can hear a faint, whispering shriek...
